Package wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver

Provides resolver classes to support resolution of conflicts in import and export functionality.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    IXConflictResolverIfc
    The interface for import resolvers.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    ContentRoleTypeConflictResolver
    This is Content role type conflict resolver.
    FolderConflictResolver
    The Folder conflict resolver.
    IXAbstractConflictResolver
    The abstract implementation for IXConflictResolverIfc.
    IXDefaultConflictResolver
    The default conflict resolver.
    IXGenericConflictResolver
    The skip object conflict resolver.
    IXMultiObjectConflictResolver
    A marker class to indicate that the resolver is capable of resolving conflict which may be related to many objects in an import session.
    IXSingleObjectConflictResolver
    A marker class to indicate that the resolver is capable of resolving conflict which is related to only one object in an import session.
    LifecycleConflictResolver
    The life-cycle template and state conflict resolver.
    NumberConflictResolver
    The Number conflict resolver.
    ObjectAlreadyExistsConflictResolver
    The object already exist conflict resolver.
    OrganizationConflictResolver
    The organization conflict resolver.
    OrganizationIDConflictResolver
    The organizationID conflict resolver.
    PrincipalReferenceConflictResolver
    The principal reference conflict resolver which handles all the conflicts related to a principal reference attribute.
    VersionResolver
    The version related resolver.

Package wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver Description

Provides resolver classes to support resolution of conflicts in import and export functionality. The resolver decides what would be the default resolution for a conflict and what additional resolution it supports for resolving a conflict.

A new resolver must implement IXConflictResolverIfc. However some of the necessary and default functionality has been encapsulated in the abstract class IXAbstractConflictResolver

Also, it is strongly recommended that while writing new resolver one should extend from either of the following marker classes:

  • IXSingleObjectConflictResolver: This would indicate that the resolver is capable of resolving conflict which is related to only one object in an import session.
  • IXMultiObjectConflictResolver: This would indicate that the resolver is capable of resolving conflict which may be related to many objects in an import session.

Sample Resolver: 

/**
 * Copyright Notice
 */
package wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver;

import <<whatever>>;

/**
 * TODO: Document me well.
 */
public class MyResolver extends  IXMultiObjectConflictResolver { // Need to extend the appropriate class as required.
    {// unnamed code-block starts
        /**
         * Optionally set a default resolution if you want to override the 
         * super's default resolution choice.
         */
        //Default resolutionType
        DEFAULT_RESOLUTION = Resolution1; // Setting 'Resolution1' as the default resolution for this resolver.

        /**
         * If you are overriding the super's default resolution, 
         * add it to all available resolution.
         * 
         * Additionally, in case you want add some more resolution, add it.
         */
        //Available resolutionType
        AVAILABLE_RESOLUTION.add(DEFAULT_RESOLUTION); // Adding the default resolution to the all available resolution which this resolver can handle.
        AVAILABLE_RESOLUTION.add(Resolution2); // Adding 'Resolution2' to all all available resolution which this resolver can handle.

    }// unnamed code-block ends

    // Resolving conflict using the 'resolutionType'
    public Object resolve(ResolutionType resolutionType, IxbElement fileXML, Importer importer, Object[] arguments) throws WTException {
        //Handle whatever resolution you want to handle

        if (Resolution1.equals(resolutionType)) { // Resolving using 'Resolution1' resolution
            //Use separate PROTECTED function, so that child may override if required
            return resolution1(fileXML, importer, arguments);

        } else if (Resolution2.equals(resolutionType)) { // Resolving using 'Resolution2' resolution
            //Use separate PROTECTED function, so that child may override if required
            return resolution2(fileXML, importer, arguments);

        }

        // If not handling, leave it to the super to handle
        else { 
            return super.resolve(resolutionType, fileXML, importer, arguments);
        }
    }

    /**
     * TODO: Document me well.
     * 
     * @param fileXML
     * @param importer
     * @param arguments
     * @return
     * @throws WTException
     */
    protected Object resolution1( IxbElement fileXML, Importer importer, Object[] arguments) throws WTException {
        // Resolve using 'Resolution1' resolution.
        // TODO
    }

    /**
     * TODO: Document me well.
     * 
     * @param fileXML
     * @param importer
     * @param arguments
     * @return
     * @throws WTException
     */
    protected Object resolution2(IxbElement fileXML, Importer importer, Object[] arguments) throws WTException {
        // Resolve using 'Resolution2' resolution.
        // TODO
    }
}

Registering the resolver in service.properties.xconf: 

<!-- Import/Export(IXB) conflict resolver delegates -->
<Service context="default" name="wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver.IXConflictResolverIfc">
    <Option cardinality="singleton" order="0" requestor="<<full class name of the object type>>" selector="<<Conflict type name>>" serviceClass="<<The new resolver>>"/>
</Service>
  • Cardinality: singleton/duplicate, depending on implementation.
  • Requestor: It represents the object type for which this resolver must be instantiated to resolve a particular conflict type.
  • Selector: The [actorName]|conflictTypeName. Please note that actorName is optional. It is possible to have a resolver resolver per [actor]conflict type.
  • ServiceClass: The full class path of the resolver. 
Example:
<Service context="default" name="wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver.IXConflictResolverIfc">
    <Option cardinality="singleton" order="0" requestor="java.lang.Object" selector="DEFAULT_IXB_CONFLICT" serviceClass="wt.ixb.conflictFramework.conflictResolution.resolver.MyResolver"/>
</Service>

Sample usage from handlers: 

    importer.generalConflictSet.addConflict(conflictType, iXBImpConflict , ixbElement, importer, paramsForResolver);
Note: paramsForResolver may be used to pass any additional object(s) which may be required by resolver for resolving, else null.
This would be passed as 'Object[] arguments' parameter to the resolver's resolve(...) api.

Important Notes:

  • From the import export applet client, the default resolution would be used to resolve conflict.
  • From the import export service while resolving conflict, if no resolver is registered in service properties for the corresponding conflict type and if the conflict can be overridden, IXDefaultConflictResolver would be used to resolve the conflict.
  • From the import export service, if the conflict cannot be overridden, IXGenericConflictResolver would be used. However for non-overridable conflict, the import export applet client would always result into error.
